body.p: Iranian jewellery and small finds in religious context
By Natascha Bagherpour Kashani
Keywords;Iran,Parthian,Sasanian,finger-rings,beads.
واژگان کلیدی: ایران، اشکانیان، ساسانیان، انگشترها، مهره ها
The items discovered in the Cale Gar mines at Vesnave have added a fresh perspective to the investigation of pre-lslamic religion, as emphasized by

Overlaet, J. Rose and P. Kreyenbroek.1 The finds from Vesnave make an important contribution to our knowledge, not only for researching pre-lslamic religion, but also for visualising the physical artefacts of ancient Iran.
The importance of the study of jewellery finds from Vesnave

In Vesnave, two mines were excavated by a team of German and Iranian archaeologists in several campaigns from 2001 to 2004.2 They discovered, mainly in Cale Gar 1, a great number of artefacts, among them jewellery - including many beads ,finger-rings, ear-rings and pendants - and fragments of metal sheets , as well as much else. It is remarkable that these objects were found in such a con- text at Vesnave, because in Iran and the wider Near East, jewellery has been unearthed predominantly in graves. To excavate such an amount of artefacts in the Cale Gar caves has been, apart from their importance for the investigation of the pre-lslamic religion, a milestone for research into small finds in Iran and the Near East in general.

The study of these objects is of great interest for the understanding of ritual practices at Vesnave, since establishing their chronology and provenance may help broaden knowledge of personal ornaments in ancient Iran.
A short introduction to the history of research into jewellery found in Iran
Jewellery from the Near East - which has much potential for fruitful comparisons to the finds from Vesnave, especially the beads - has been methodically investigated by a number of scholars. One of
C f. contributions by Overlaet, Rose and Kreyenbroek, in this volume,
Stollner/Mir Eskanderi 2003.

the most famous works is by H. Beck , who assembled the first classification system for beads . Other essential publications include those by P. Francis on Asian beads ; B. Musche on Parthian and Sasanian jewellery; M. Spaer on glass in the Israel Museum; and a revealing article by St. J. Simpson on Sasanian beads . Wide-ranging excavation reports and investigations of jewellery offer a spectrum of comparisons for the finds at Vesnave-.^ However, Near Eastern archaeology and, in particular, Iranian archaeology lack a basic study of cultic and everyday material of the kind found at Vesnave. Regarding the Sasanian period, Simpson writes: “Corresponding studies of everyday material culture are scarce yet a number of sites have been excavated (.,.)a

For a description of mine Gale Gar 1 , the reader is referred to the article by Thomas Stollner in this volume. A large amount of artefacts were discovered there, while Cale Gar 2 yielded just a few finds from a humid corner. Ceramics, whether complete vessels or fragments, were found in mine 1; further fragments of textiles , animal bones , wood and wooden vessels , as well as other organic material like nuts and baked remains , were also found there.

Among the finds from Cale Gar 1 and 2, small finds - jewellery artefacts primarily - represent a significant group. First and foremost, beads and pendants are a major group, made by different techniques and from different materials, but mainly glass and stone. Furthermore, coins, metal finger and ear-rings and a glass finger-ring were discovered, as well as figurative objects, inlays, settings, chain links, a few ornaments for clothes, bells and metal sheets (plain or with figurative or plant depiction
N. Bagherpour Kashani). Other finds include a glass vessel and a fragment of one, an arrow head, a strap-end, and a whetstone.
N. Bagherpour Kashani
The date of the Sacred Cave 1

So far, it has proven possible to date mine 1 at Vesnave roughly by C-analysis and by coin finds. From the bottom of the cultic context, charcoal was collected and analysed. The beginning of cultic activity can thus be assigned to 900-781 BC, while the use of the site seems to have ended in the early Islamic period, based on the final coin find (Fig. I).10 This coin is a silver derham of the Umayyad period. Due to its state of preservation, it is not possible to read the date, but limits can be set between 661 and 750 AD. Other finds seem to confirm these chronological limits for the sacrificial cave (see below).

Although charcoal and coins indicate the beginning and the rough end of the use of the cave as a holy place, they can obviously not demonstrate the kind of use, the manner of deposition and the changes during the c. 1500 years of its existence for that purpose. Examining jewellery found in Cale Gar 1 and 2 will answer some of these questions. Investigations may be able to specify the dates of the deposits and give insights into the procedure of deposition.

Following is a general introduction to the beads and finger-rings from Vesnave, followed by the presentation of selected find groups, such as gold-in-glass beads, etched carnelian beads and finger-rings with bird ornaments, spirals and one find with a conical bezel.
Beads, pendants and spacers

Beads - quantified simply by their number - account for the largest part of small finds at Vesnave. They consist of many different materials, but predominantly glass, and were fabricated using different

techniques. The excavators found beads of monochrome opaque or translucent glass, and their colours were mainly yellow, green, dark/black, brown and different shades of blue. Few beads were turquoise, lilac, orange or white. An analysis of the material has not yet been carried out, therefore concerning the opaque beads, it is not clear whether they were originally manufactured of frit or glass; but it seems that they mainly consist of glass.12

Some beads are multi-coloured, others consist of two different coloured layers. So-called mosaic beads, different kinds of eye beads and so-called gold-in-glass beads stand out from the assemblage.13 Their manufacturing processes are of great interest; that used for the gold-in-glass beads will be explained below. Besides colours, the Vesnave beads have different shapes; they vary from simple spherical beads to disc, cylindrical, double-conical, rectangular, rhombic, hexagonal shapes, corner-less cube and so-called melon-shaped beads (No. 6448, Fig. 2).

Besides glass ones, stone beads make up a large proportion of the finds. These are mainly carnelian beads of shapes similar to those named above; but other materials used include garnet, jet, chalcedony, rock crystal, hematite, plus a few of turquoise and lapis lazuli of poor quality. More precious beads were made of silver, gold and amber, while some other beads were made of bone, cowry and other shells.

Eisen wrote: “A bead is a unit of a necklace and perforated by one or several bores”.* This definition should be further elaborated. A bead is usually a small artefact of a specific shape and made from a specific material; it can be worn as a necklace with other beads, sewn on to textiles or connected to fibulae or other objects. In Vesnave, the beads were obviously not deposited in the form of necklaces, but as single items. Thus, a bead can present itself as an individual object. Its characteristic is the string-hole through the middle, while pendants have a peripheral hole and spacers two or more holes. Identified at Vesnave and fitting this categorisation are several pendants made of glass, stone, bronze and amber and two spacer beads, one of glass and one of lapis lazuli.

body.p: Iranian jewellery and small finds in religious context

A significant category discovered solely in mine 1 are the so-called etched carnelian beads. These artefacts are of simple shapes and ornamented by white zig-zag lines, waves, dots or a “plant-like” pattern (Fig. 3,a-c). As mentioned above. Beck, “the founding father of bead studies”, was the first to establish a chronology of the manufacture of etched carnelian beads. He distinguished three phases: the early period. A, which ended ca. 2000 BC; the middle period, B, from 300 BC to AD 200; and the late period, C, AD 600 to 1000. This chronological framework is still consulted frequently as an important source for studies of etched carnelian beads. However, hiatuses in the dating are obvious. Later works by E. Mackay, M. Dikshit, E. During Caspers, J. Reade, A. de Waele and E. Haerinck expanded Beck's studies, but did not fill the gaps completely. Although no recent study of etched beads has succeeded in presenting an adapted chronology for the entire Near East, etched carnelian beads are discussed more often than other kinds of stone beads, because, unlike plain carnelian beads, their ornamentation tends to be chronologically significant.

Fig. 3,a-cEtched carnelian beads from Cale Gar 1 at Vesnave. Find nos. 1679b, 1106,1577. L 1.1 cm- 1.4 cm. Scale 2:1. Photos and drawings © DBMThe reason why such decoration remains preserved today and has not been washed away, lies in a special method of decorating stone beads “used in South Asia as early as the mid-3rd millennium BC'. Etching them while applying an alkaline solution together with heat made the white ornamentation firm against corrosion. The earliest finds of etched carnelian beads appeared in Mesopotamia and the Indus Valley; indeed, the latter seems to be the region of their origin. In 1930, E. Mackay travelled to Sindh/lndia to learn the technique of etching carnelian beads, and three years later an account of his experience was published in the journal “Man”;
Fig. 3,a-c
Etched carnelian beads from Cale Gar 1 at Vesnave. Find nos. 1679b, 1106,1577. L 1.1 cm- 1.4 cm. Scale 2:1. Photos and drawings © DBM

“First, he [the craftsman] carefully macerated the tips of young shoots of a bush that is common in Sindh and the Panjab, capparis aphylla (Sindhi: Kirar), in a glazed pottery bowl with the aid of a wooden stick with a rounded end. (...) Sahebdino{name of person} [the craftsman] then ground ordinary European

washing soda to a fine powder, and after carefully mixing it with water in a cup, he poured a small quantity on the Kirar together to a semi-fluid mass. This the old man strained through a piece of linen into a large empty mussel-shell, and the paint was ready. A piece of polished red carnelian, such as a bead or plaque for a talisman or ring, is then fixed in a setting made of clay mixed with cotton-wool. When the setting is dry, an inscription or design is

N. Bagherpour Kashaniwritten or drawn upon the exposed polished surface of the cornelian with a reed pen filled with the paint (...) A sure and steady hand is needed to prepare an elaborate design, for re-touching can only be done successfully before baking, and even then traces of bungling may be evident. The painted piece of cornelian, still in its setting, is placed on a piece of sheet-iron and laid on the embers of a charcoal fire until the design is perfectly dry. The cornelian is then buried in the embers and the fire slowly fanned for about five minutes. The stone on removal from the fire is taken from its clay setting and placed under a small cup to cool down gradually. After about ten minutes it is sufficiently cooled, and at this stage Sahebdino rubbed his piece of cornelian briskly with a rag(…)”
N. Bagherpour Kashani

There can be little room for doubt that carnelian beads were etched by a similar process in pre-Islamic times. Besides technical capability, learning from experience is essential to etch stones: Not every carnelian is equally fireproof: some stones turn pink, white or even opaque when heated too much or too long.22

At Vesnave, seventeen ornamented carnelian beads were found. They vary from fragmented to the complete, and from orange to red in colour. They correspond to Beck’s Type I with a white pattern on bare stone.23 By comparing parallel finds from Hassani Mahale, Rudbar {place} and Djuben {place}, all sites in the northern Iranian province of Gilan {place}, it would appear that the Cale Gar beads with simple patterns of dots or lines should be dated to the 1st mill. BC; but their rough shape, careless decoration and the colour of the stone indicate a later dating, i.e. at least the end of the 1st mill. BC or the 1st centuries AD.24 Other beads with zig-zags, dots and crosswise decorations seem to belong to the centuries after Christ, particularly the Sasanian period, i.e. from the 3rd to the 7th century.25 Analogies are known from the region of Germi in northern Iran and from Ed-Dur in Arabia.26

More elaborate “plant” decorations date from the late Sasanian or early Islamic period. At Vesnave, two pieces with such adornments have been discovered. Comparisons exist from a grave in Samad/Arabia

As impressive as the etched beads are the so-called gold-in-glass beads, which have been discovered in Cale Gar 1. They have not been found in large numbers, but they are beautifully produced pieces for which a special technique was employed: a gold foil is applied on a glass core and then enclosed in translucent, colourless glass. This manufacturing technique gave them a fine appearance, and analysing it helps to date them. These beads were abundant from Antiquity to Medieval times, and have been discovered in Asia, as well as in Europe, including Great Britain. On the island of Rhodes, remains of unfinished gold-in-glass beads were found and dated to the late 3rd cent. BC.

G. Boon and Spaer suggest Egypt as the region of origin for the gold-in-glass method of manufacture, while D. Barag argues that it emanated from Phoenician roots and other scholars prefer India. As an early instance of gold-in-glass manufacturing, the so-called Canosa Group of the 1st half of the 3rd cent. BC has been considered by several scholars. This refers to two well preserved glass bowls with decorated golden inlays, found alongside eight glasses, in a grave in southern Italy, having probably been produced in a Ptolemaic workshop. According to D. Harden and A. Oliver, no gold-in-glass beads have been found of an earlier date than the Canosa Group. This fact, together with the remains of the glass workshop at Rhodes that date to the late 3rd century BC, implies that gold-in-glass beads were not produced before the 3rd cent. BC, in particular the late 3rd century. As mentioned above, such beads continued to be produced into medieval times, though evidence for continuity of manufacture in the Islamic Near East is scarce.

Special skill and experience were needed to produce gold-in-glass beads. The craftsman had to put a flimsy gold sheet on a glass core and cover this combination with translucent glass. The two glass layers should then respond equally to heat, i.e. they should have the same coefficient of expansion; otherwise the glass would break during the process. Another challenge was not to harm the gold foil that could be as thin as 0.0001 mm, and so was very easily damaged.35 According to Spaer, earlier beads were finished individually, and show larger string-holes and a thicker exterior glass layer; these were of better quality. In later times beads were treated with tools and probably moulds.36 Grooves in the glass point to fabrication of the beads by drawing glass tubes: “A drawn tube was, after cooling, covered with a very thin layer of metal foil, probably attached with the aid of an adhesive. Another, slightly larger, pre-manufactured tube was then slipped over the first.”. This gold-in-glass tube was then divided by a tool into single beads, or into beads with two or more segments. Spaer writes furthermore: “(...) There is nonetheless a clear indication that the beads finished individually by hot-working are Hellenistic and probably, at least in part, also early Roman. Beads finished by the use of segmenting molds are mainly Roman or later ”38

At Vesnave, about 20 gold-in-glass beads (complete or fragmented) were excavated. They may either be carefully hot-worked single spherical beads; or they are ovaloid, cylindrical, multi-row, “collared” or of the so-called mulberry-shape. The majority are quite well conserved, and preserve their original brilliance (Fig. 4,a-c).

The only collared bead and the segmented beads can be dated to a somewhat later period, on the basis of comparisons to artefacts from Tappe Hatam/northern Iran and Hassani Mahale/ northern Iran.40 They belong to the Parthian and early

Parallel examples from Crimea and Hassani Mahale/northern Iran, together with the special shape and manufacturing method, allow us to assign this object to the centuries between the 1st and 3rd cent. AD. According to Spaer, mulberry beads with small bosses belong to the late Hellenistic and early Roman periods, and then went out of fashion in the 1st cent. AD: Then “(...) cruder beads with larger bosses came into use.”41
limitations

It is significant that further beads were found in Cale Gar 1, which do not belong with the gold-in-glass beads yet seem to imitate these. They can be identified as double-layered, but instead of being covered by a gold foil, they are coated by a yellow layer or an orange- or yellow-coloured translucent exterior glass layer. At Vesnave, eight pieces were considered to be imitations of gold-in-glass beads. Their shapes include the single-spherical, the double- and the triple-rowed. It appears that these kinds of beads were produced as imitations in periods later than the genuine gold-in-glass beads, at least after the gold-in-glass technique had been fully developed. Apparently not much attention has yet been paid to objects of this kind, because comparisons scarcely exist in the available literature.

Obviously the gold-in-glass beads at Vesnave point to a chronological range from the beginning of gold-in-glass production in the 3rd cent. BC until the 3rd century AD, at least on account of the group of spherical, carefully worked beads. The group of segmented beads very probably belong to the centuries AD, stretching into the early Sasanian period, the 3rd to 4th cent. AD, while the only mulberry bead belongs to the two centuries either side of the birth of Christ. The imitations may date to a later period, perhaps the late Sasanian - or even, at a stretch, early Islamic times. As Spaer has judged, the manufacture of gold-in-glass beads probably continued in Egypt and western Asia well into the Islamic era, but the evidence is meager; and then, already, greater numbers were being produced in Europe.42

Because of a lack of material analysis for the most metal objects, it is not always clear whether or not the material of the ring has been determined correctly in each case. Additionally, the iron rings are heavily corroded, and so, in many cases, it is not ascertainable whether they were finger-rings or ear-rings.

However, at least one third of the rings are well preserved - assorted copper, bronze and silver - and they have been partially restored. They contain bezels, and some are ornamented with figurative or non-figurative incisions. Others have bezels containing inlays (at least one piece), and some still contain green or blue glass (four pieces). One ring is made of a piece of bronze wire and its ends are two overlapping spirals. Forty-two finger- rings have been verified as having incisions. The decoration of the rings has been applied on the wider part of the ring or on a round, ovaloid, rhomb-shaped, quadrangular or rectangular bezel, most of which is stepped and in some cases Insetted (Fig. 5). The ornaments are birds and one gryphon (21 pieces), a stag (one piece), schematic plant illustrations (three pieces), pseudo-inscriptions (three pieces) and different non-figurative incisions such as lines, circles with dots and a cross or rings of modelled metal (seven pieces). Descriptions of some of the finger-rings found at Vesnave now follow.
Glass finger-ring

The only glass ring from Vesnave is a beautiful piece made of a striped hoop (Fig. 6). It was manufactured of twisted yellow and translucent colourless glass, and a blue-white eye of opaque glass was applied as a bezel on the top of it. Such glass rings were both worn in everyday life and dedicated to sanctuaries.

A technique of producing larger glass rings for bracelets is described by Manfred Korfmann: hot monochrome glass is taken out of the furnace by winding a conical-ended rod, and the turning and swelling of the rod produce a larger inner diameter of the ring; then, by help of a tool, the former ring bead is formed into a seamless bracelet.

However, in the case of the glass ring from Vesnave, the method seems to have been different; this is strongly suggested by the thinning of the hoop and discontinuity or inconsistency in the yellow stripes just below the bezel. Obviously a bi-coloured glass rod was produced first, then reheated and its ends joined together. Similar observations concerning technique and appearance can be made using parallels from Gilan/northem Iran and from the Nasser D. Khalili Collection. They are made of translucent yellow glass plunged by stripes of yellow and whitish opaque glass and seem to have been produced in the same way as the piece from Vesnave. Their bezel consists of one red eye.

The piece from Gilan/ Northern Iran belongs to the 1st—3rd cent. AD, while the ring from the Nasser D, Khalili Collection is roughly dated to the 1st—7-1 cent. AD; the latter is believed to derive from Syria or Iran.

Metal finger-rings: “Bird-rings”
Turning to the metal finger-rings of Cale Gar 1, most of the ornamented rings show a bird. The animal symbols are either embossed carefully or inscribed by rough incisions (Fig. 5).
Dating the “bird-rings”

In Qasr-e ’Abu Nasr near Shiraz/southern Iran and in the tombs of Nubian Qustul/Egypt, rings have been discovered also showing bird symbols. With their ovaloid and triangular bezels, and hoops that too have similarities, they correspond to the shapes of the Vesnave rings. These pieces from southern Iran and Egypt respectively were dated to a period between 300 BC and 400 AD; and to ca. 800 AD.49

It seems that bird symbols were used over many generations in Iran and other regions. On Roman gems we find birds depicted, and even in contemporary Iran, birds represent a positive symbol and are believed to bring good luck.50
Frye 1973, nos. 33-47: Musche 1988, 309 PI. 108, top left; Beyer Williams 1991, Pi. 73,o,
Henig/MacGregor 2004, 96 Fig. 9; 102,9.105.

While the “bird-rings” appeared in great number at Vesnave, the spiral finger-ring is the only example of its kind, but a very significant one (Fig. 7). It is made of a piece of bronze wire, the ends of which are combined to create two overlapping spirals.

Already from the Mycenean period, the 2nd half of the 2nd cent. BC, a golden ring with just a single spiral is known, while a bronze ring with two spirals dates back to the so-called Geometric period, c. 900-800 BC. These examples do not match the piece from Vesnave exactly. Their overall appearance is different, because they were made more carefully; furthermore, neither has overlapping spirals. Rings with overlapping spirals seem to have appeared in later times, as for example a golden finger-ring in the British Museum which belongs to the late Roman period, the 3rd/4th cent. AD, and a variant from Masjed-e Soleyman/lran, made of two twisted bronze wires, of the Parthian period, i.e. 3rd cent. BC - AD 3rd cent. Four bronze pieces with overlapping spirals were found at Cheragali Tappe/ Gilan/lran, and were dated to the Sasanian period, the 3rd to 7th centuries AD.

In an upper layer of Cale Gar 1, another unique bronze finger-ring was excavated, and its shape points to a late date of manufacture. The ring features a rectangular-based but conical bezel with a crosswise decoration (Fig. 8).
Dating rings with a conical shaped bezel

An analogous bronze shape is found in the Nasser D. Khalili Collection and dates to the 7th or 8th centuries AD. In this regard, it is especially interesting that the editor of the report on the finger-rings of the Nasser D. Khalili Collection mentioned comparable items from Mostagedda/Middle Egypt, dated to about AD 800, and from an excavation at Rey/ Iran. Another Iranian example has been found from the Islamic Neishapur of the 7th to 12th cent. AD. On the basis of these comparisons, even though they either come from collections or are dated quite roughly, it is plausible that the ring found at Vesnave belongs to the early Islamic period.

One piece obviously resembles a fish, another a bird. One silver sheet is embossed with a figure, the gender of which has yet to be discussed.
Weapons are rare at Vesnave, the only offensive weapon being a bronze arrow head (Fig. 10); its head is double-bladed and leaf-shaped with a spike at the cylindrical socket.

Analogies to the arrow head have been found in Bogazkoy in Turkey, and have been dated to the 7th cent. BC; in Ziwiye, Iran, from the Hasanlu IIIB period, 750-600 BC; and from Zendan-e Soleyman, Iran, from the 2nd quarter of the 7th cent. BC. As the comparisons show, the arrow head dates to the beginning of the site’s use as a votive place. It is either an early deposit or an acquisition which entered the cave at a later date.
Conclusion

Of the many finds of Vesnave, just a few have been presented here, but they give an indication of the chronology of the jewellery deposited and found in mine 1. Although the sacrificial site had already been in use from about the 8th cent. BC, obviously jewellery was deposited at Vesnave not earlier than 300 BC, centuries after the first ritual use of the caves as recorded in the votive deposit.

This agrees with beads and rings being distributed predominantly in the front part of cave 1. Additionally, the artefacts show that there was a peak period for depositing jewellery in the centuries AD, a hypothesis supported by finds of coins from the time of the Parthian and Sasanian kings. Furthermore, the Umayyad coin and discoveries of a finger-ring and beads indicate that people deposited objects at Vesnave until early Islamic times, albeit few.
The artefacts from Vesnave found in Cale Gar 1 and 2 are related to one another and seem to have a special meaning, since they were used as

body.p: Nonetheless, based on the finds which are discussed in this article, some statements can be made already; Jewellery always had a particular part to play in oblation, and in Cale Gar 1 a significant amount was found. Some categories of jewellery, such as the plain carnelian beads, seem to have been quite common, while others were more distinctive and hence valuable. For example, etched carnelian beads and gold-in-glass beads were especially precious objects in a rural region in the ancient world, their manufacture requiring special skills. Like the amber beads discovered, they may be imports from far afield.60 As for the “bird” finger-rings, their symbols and meaning must have been familiar to the ancient people of Vesnave since they were deposited frequently. The glass finger-ring, the metal sheets and the only weapon not merely represent exceptional finds, but also still leave many questions unanswered.

Summary

Jewellery incorporates a significant category among the finds from the caves Cale Gar 1 and 2 at Vesna- ve. Selected find groups are described and compared to analogies from sites in Iran and elsewhere in the Near East. Most comparisons from Iran originate from the northern province of GTlan or tfie region of Germi in East Azarbaijan, whereas few are from Nei- sapur and Qasr-e Abu Nasr, respectively in northeastern and southern Iran. Beyond Iran, comparable finds come from Crimea, Egypt and Ed-Dur in Arabia. Already - as described here - etched camelian beads, so-called gold-in-glass beads and several finger-rings give an indication of the chronology of Cale Gar 1 jewellery deposits, and a preliminary assessment of their meaning can be made. Metal sheets and an arrow head are also discussed.
